sources: West Virginia Division of Natural Resources (WVDNR)
Kentucky Department of Fish & Wildlife Resources
Alabama Department of Conservation and Natural Resources
Mississippi Department of Wildlife, Fisheries, and Parks (MDWFP)
notes: Regulations are subject to change. Always verify with official state agencies before fishing.
Many states have specific water body exceptions to statewide regulations.
Some regulations vary by geographic sub-regions within states.
Emergency orders and proclamations may supersede published regulations.
Trout stamp or special permits may be required for certain species or waters.

license_requirements.freshwater: Fishing license required for residents age 15+ and all non-residents. Trout stamp required when targeting trout.
license_requirements.notes: License and identification must be carried while fishing. Resident 65+ pay reduced rates ($9 annual).

species.bag_limit_notes: 6 black bass per day (all Micropterus species combined)
species.special_regulations: Some water bodies have different regulations - check WVDNR for specific exceptions

species.bag_limit_notes: 6 black bass per day (all Micropterus species combined)
species.special_regulations: Some water bodies have different regulations

species.bag_limit_notes: 6 black bass per day (all Micropterus species combined)
species.special_regulations: Included in combined black bass limit

species.bag_limit_notes: 30 daily, 60 possession on most waters; 4 daily, 8 possession on designated impoundments
species.special_regulations: Limits vary by water body type

species.minimum_size_notes: Only one may be 35 inches or longer on select waters
species.bag_limit_notes: 2 daily on most waters; 4 daily (only one over 35 inches) with 8 possession (only 2 over 35 inches) on select waters
species.special_regulations: Trophy size restrictions apply on select waters

species.minimum_size_notes: Only one may be 35 inches or longer
species.bag_limit_notes: 4 daily, only one may be 35 inches or longer
species.special_regulations: Trophy size restriction for large fish

species.bag_limit_notes: 30 per day combined with white crappie (in aggregate)
species.special_regulations: Effective January 1, 2026; combined limit with white crappie

species.bag_limit_notes: 30 per day combined with black crappie (in aggregate)
species.special_regulations: Effective January 1, 2026; combined limit with black crappie

species.minimum_size_notes: Various size requirements apply to specific rivers and lakes
species.bag_limit_notes: 8 daily, 16 possession on most waters; special regulations on specific waters
species.special_regulations: Size and creel limits vary by water body

species.bag_limit_notes: 6 daily, 12 possession; special regulations in catch-and-release and delayed-harvest areas
species.special_regulations: Trout stamp required. Delayed-harvest sections have seasonal restrictions. Check stocking schedule at wvdnr.gov
species.geographic_restrictions: Designated trout waters; special catch-and-release areas

species.bag_limit_notes: 6 daily, 12 possession; combined with other trout species
species.special_regulations: Trout stamp required. Some waters have naturally reproducing populations.

species.bag_limit_notes: 6 daily, 12 possession; combined with other trout species
species.special_regulations: Trout stamp required. Native to high-elevation headwaters in Allegheny Mountains.
species.geographic_restrictions: High-elevation streams and designated trout waters

species.minimum_size_notes: Only 5 fish may be 8 inches or longer
species.bag_limit_notes: 10 daily combined with all other sunfish species (in aggregate), only 5 may be 8 inches or longer
species.special_regulations: Size restriction designed to protect spawning-age fish

license_requirements.notes: Many lakes have special regulations that differ from statewide limits. Reciprocal agreement with Tennessee on Kentucky Lake.

species.bag_limit_notes: 6 daily, 12 possession; some waters have 15-inch minimum
species.special_regulations: Special regulations apply to specific lakes - check fw.ky.gov for water body exceptions

species.bag_limit_notes: 6 daily, 12 possession; some waters have 15-inch minimum

species.bag_limit_notes: 6 daily, 12 possession; Kentucky state fish
species.special_regulations: Also known as Kentucky Bass; state fish designated 1956
species.geographic_restrictions: Primarily in streams with clear water and moderate to swift current

species.minimum_size_notes: Only 1 fish may exceed 25 inches
species.bag_limit_notes: 15 fish aggregate daily limit for blue and channel catfish combined; only 1 fish may be longer than 25 inches
species.special_regulations: Combined aggregate limit with blue catfish

species.bag_limit_notes: 15 fish aggregate daily limit for blue and channel catfish combined; only 1 fish may be longer than 25 inches

species.special_regulations: Combined with white crappie for creel limit

species.special_regulations: Combined with black crappie for creel limit

species.minimum_size_notes: 14 inches on Ohio River; varies by water body
species.bag_limit_notes: 6 daily on Ohio River (combined with sauger and saugeye); varies by water body

species.bag_limit_notes: 2 per day statewide. Harvest prohibited in Lake Mitchell, Lay Dam tailrace, Walnut Creek, Hatchet Creek, Weogufka Creek, Mulberry Fork River, Sipsey Fork River, their tributaries, and Duck River Reservoir.
species.special_regulations: Multiple waters closed to walleye harvest; must be released immediately if caught
species.geographic_restrictions: Specific closures in Coosa River system and northern Alabama waters

species.special_regulations: 15-inch minimum size; part of aggregate sportfish limit

species.bag_limit_notes: 20 fish per day aggregate; 12-inch minimum. North Mississippi Flood Control Reservoirs (Arkabutla, Sardis, Enid, Grenada) have specific boat creel limits; Sardis allows 40 legal crappie per boat with 3+ licensed anglers.
species.special_regulations: Special boat creel limits on flood control reservoirs; part of aggregate sportfish limit
species.geographic_restrictions: Statewide with special regulations on flood control reservoirs

species.special_regulations: Special boat creel limits on flood control reservoirs; part of aggregate sportfish limit
species.geographic_restrictions: Statewide with special regulations on flood control reservoirs

regional_characteristics: Southeast Interior states share similar freshwater species and fishing opportunities
Many states have reciprocal agreements on border waters (Tennessee River, Kentucky Lake, etc.)
Trophy size restrictions common for catfish species to protect large, old fish
Crappie fishing is extremely popular throughout the region
Bass fishing regulations vary significantly - Tennessee has no creel limit while other states do
Most states have moved toward protecting larger spawning-age panfish
data_gaps: Some specific water body exceptions not fully documented
Seasonal trout stocking schedules vary and should be checked with state agencies
Exact coordinates for state centers are approximate
Some panfish species (redear sunfish, green sunfish, etc.) not fully documented
White bass regulations not fully detailed for all states
Pike and muskie information limited due to restricted range in these states
recommendations: Always verify current regulations with state wildlife agencies before fishing
Check for emergency orders and special proclamations
Download state-specific fishing apps or carry regulation guides
Be aware of water body-specific exceptions to statewide regulations
Understand proper fish measurement techniques (total length)
Know the difference between daily creel limits and possession limits
Verify reciprocal agreement details when fishing border waters
Purchase required licenses, stamps, and permits before fishing

key_differences_between_states.bass_regulations: Tennessee has no creel limit, others range from 6-10 fish
key_differences_between_states.catfish_limits: West Virginia most restrictive for blue catfish; Mississippi and Tennessee least restrictive
key_differences_between_states.crappie_minimums: Range from none (West Virginia) to 12 inches (Mississippi)
key_differences_between_states.senior_exemptions: Vary by state - some at 65+, amounts differ
key_differences_between_states.trout_fishing: West Virginia has most extensive trout program; limited in other states
